segment.source: Add drivers before deployment on an offline Windows image by using DISM
segment.target: Add drivers before deployment on an offline Windows image by using DISM

segment.source: Offline servicing occurs when you modify a Windows image entirely offline without booting the operating system.
segment.target: Offline servicing occurs when you modify a Windows image entirely offline without booting the operating system.

segment.source: You can add, remove, and enumerate drivers on an offline Windows image by using the DISM command-line tool.
segment.target: You can add, remove, and enumerate drivers on an offline Windows image by using the DISM command-line tool.

segment.source: DISM is installed with Windows and is also distributed in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).
segment.target: DISM is installed with Windows and is also distributed in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).

segment.source: For more information about DISM, see the DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.
segment.target: For more information about DISM, see the DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.

segment.source: When you add a driver to an offline image, it's either staged or reflected in the image:
segment.target: When you add a driver to an offline image, it's either staged or reflected in the image:

segment.source: Boot-critical drivers are reflected.
segment.target: Boot-critical drivers are reflected.

segment.source: In other words, the files are copied into the image according to what's specified in the .inf file.
segment.target: In other words, the files are copied into the image according to what's specified in the .inf file.

segment.source: The PC completes installation tasks during the initial boot, including updating the Critical Devices Database (CDDB) and the registry.
segment.target: The PC completes installation tasks during the initial boot, including updating the Critical Devices Database (CDDB) and the registry.

segment.source: Drivers that aren't boot critical are staged.
segment.target: Drivers that aren't boot critical are staged.

segment.source: In other words, they're added to the driver store.
segment.target: In other words, they're added to the driver store.

segment.source: After Windows starts, PnP detects the device and installs the matching driver from the driver store.
segment.target: After Windows starts, PnP detects the device and installs the matching driver from the driver store.

segment.source: Managing Driver Folders
segment.target: Managing Driver Folders

segment.source: If you're adding multiple drivers, you should create separate folders for each driver or driver category.
segment.target: If you're adding multiple drivers, you should create separate folders for each driver or driver category.

segment.source: This makes sure that there are no conflicts when you add drivers that have the same file name.
segment.target: This makes sure that there are no conflicts when you add drivers that have the same file name.

segment.source: After the driver is installed on the operating system, it's renamed to Oem.inf to ensure unique file names in the operating system.
segment.target: After the driver is installed on the operating system, it's renamed to Oem.inf to ensure unique file names in the operating system.

segment.source: For example, the staged drivers named MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed to Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf after they're installed.
segment.target: For example, the staged drivers named MyDriver1.inf and MyDriver2.inf are renamed to Oem0.inf and Oem1.inf after they're installed.

segment.source: When you specify a device-driver path in an answer file, all .inf drivers in the specified directory and subdirectories are added to the driver store of the Windows image.
segment.target: When you specify a device-driver path in an answer file, all .inf drivers in the specified directory and subdirectories are added to the driver store of the Windows image.

segment.source: For example, if you want all of the drivers in the C:MyDriversNetworking, C:MyDriversVideo, and C:MyDriversAudio directories to be available in your Windows image, specify the device-driver path, C:MyDrivers, in your answer file.
segment.target: For example, if you want all of the drivers in the C:MyDriversNetworking, C:MyDriversVideo, and C:MyDriversAudio directories to be available in your Windows image, specify the device-driver path, C:MyDrivers, in your answer file.

segment.source: This command makes sure that all drivers in each subdirectory will be added to the driver store in your Windows image.
segment.target: This command makes sure that all drivers in each subdirectory will be added to the driver store in your Windows image.

segment.source: Understanding Driver Ranking
segment.target: Understanding Driver Ranking

segment.source: One of the most common issues in deploying drivers happens when a driver is successfully imported into the driver store but, after the system is online, PnP finds a higher-ranking driver and installs that driver instead.
segment.target: One of the most common issues in deploying drivers happens when a driver is successfully imported into the driver store but, after the system is online, PnP finds a higher-ranking driver and installs that driver instead.

segment.source: The Windows PnP manager ranks these driver package properties in order of importance:
segment.target: The Windows PnP manager ranks these driver package properties in order of importance:

segment.source: Signing
segment.target: Signing

segment.source: PnP ID match
segment.target: PnP ID match

segment.source: Driver date
segment.target: Driver date

segment.source: Driver version
segment.target: Driver version

segment.source: For example, if a device has a better PnP ID match but is unsigned, a signed driver that has a compatible ID match takes precedence.
segment.target: For example, if a device has a better PnP ID match but is unsigned, a signed driver that has a compatible ID match takes precedence.

segment.source: An older driver can outrank a newer driver if the older driver has a better PnP ID match or signature.
segment.target: An older driver can outrank a newer driver if the older driver has a better PnP ID match or signature.

segment.source: For more information about driver ranking, see How Windows Ranks Drivers.
segment.target: For more information about driver ranking, see How Windows Ranks Drivers.

segment.source: Understanding Digital Signature Requirements
segment.target: Understanding Digital Signature Requirements

segment.source: Signed device drivers are a key security feature in Windows.
segment.target: Signed device drivers are a key security feature in Windows.

segment.source: Drivers that are installed on x64-based computers must have a digital signature.
segment.target: Drivers that are installed on x64-based computers must have a digital signature.

segment.source: Although it isn't required, we recommend making sure that drivers are signed before you install them on x86-based computers.
segment.target: Although it isn't required, we recommend making sure that drivers are signed before you install them on x86-based computers.

segment.source: All boot-critical drivers must contain embedded signatures.
segment.target: All boot-critical drivers must contain embedded signatures.

segment.source: A digital signature isn't required for Plug and Play (PnP) drivers.
segment.target: A digital signature isn't required for Plug and Play (PnP) drivers.

segment.source: But when an unsigned PnP driver is installed on a running operating system, administrator credentials are required, and you can't install such drivers on 64-bit operating systems.
segment.target: But when an unsigned PnP driver is installed on a running operating system, administrator credentials are required, and you can't install such drivers on 64-bit operating systems.

segment.source: There are two ways that a driver can be signed:
segment.target: There are two ways that a driver can be signed:

segment.source: Kernel mode and boot-critical drivers are digitally signed via a method called embedded signing.
segment.target: Kernel mode and boot-critical drivers are digitally signed via a method called embedded signing.

segment.source: By using embedded signatures, every binary in the driver package is signed.
segment.target: By using embedded signatures, every binary in the driver package is signed.

segment.source: Embedded signatures improve boot loading performance.
segment.target: Embedded signatures improve boot loading performance.

segment.source: For drivers that are not PnP, signatures should be embedded so that they're not lost during an upgrade of the operating system.
segment.target: For drivers that are not PnP, signatures should be embedded so that they're not lost during an upgrade of the operating system.

segment.source: Digitally signed PnP drivers contain a catalog (.cat) file that's digitally signed.
segment.target: Digitally signed PnP drivers contain a catalog (.cat) file that's digitally signed.

segment.source: The catalog file contains a hash of all the files in the driver's .inf file for installation.
segment.target: The catalog file contains a hash of all the files in the driver's .inf file for installation.

segment.source: A signed catalog file is all that's required to correctly install most PnP drivers.
segment.target: A signed catalog file is all that's required to correctly install most PnP drivers.

segment.source: Either of these sources can sign drivers:
segment.target: Either of these sources can sign drivers:

segment.source: Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL), which makes sure that your drivers qualify for the Windows Hardware Certification Program.
segment.target: Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL), which makes sure that your drivers qualify for the Windows Hardware Certification Program.

segment.source: WHQL creates a signed driver catalog.
segment.target: WHQL creates a signed driver catalog.

segment.source: For boot-critical drivers, you should add embedded signatures instead of relying on the catalog.
segment.target: For boot-critical drivers, you should add embedded signatures instead of relying on the catalog.

segment.source: Embedded signatures in boot-critical driver image files optimize boot performance of the operating system by eliminating the requirement to locate the appropriate catalog file when the operating system loader verifies the driver signature.
segment.target: Embedded signatures in boot-critical driver image files optimize boot performance of the operating system by eliminating the requirement to locate the appropriate catalog file when the operating system loader verifies the driver signature.

segment.source: A certification authority (CA), by using a Software Publishing Certificate (SPC).
segment.target: A certification authority (CA), by using a Software Publishing Certificate (SPC).

segment.source: For boot-critical and x64-based kernel drivers, Microsoft provides an additional certificate that can be used to cross-sign the drivers.
segment.target: For boot-critical and x64-based kernel drivers, Microsoft provides an additional certificate that can be used to cross-sign the drivers.

segment.source: Drivers that aren't boot critical don't have to be cross-signed by Microsoft or embedded.
segment.target: Drivers that aren't boot critical don't have to be cross-signed by Microsoft or embedded.

segment.source: You can use the Windows Kernel Mode Code Signing process if you need the flexibility of signing the drivers yourself.
segment.target: You can use the Windows Kernel Mode Code Signing process if you need the flexibility of signing the drivers yourself.

segment.source: For information about digital signatures for kernel modules on x64-based systems, see 64-Bit Driver Guidelines.
segment.target: For information about digital signatures for kernel modules on x64-based systems, see 64-Bit Driver Guidelines.

segment.source: For testing, you can also use test certificates.
segment.target: For testing, you can also use test certificates.

segment.source: If you have received an unsigned driver from a vendor for testing, you can use a test signature to validate the driver and to test the installation.
segment.target: If you have received an unsigned driver from a vendor for testing, you can use a test signature to validate the driver and to test the installation.

segment.source: Test signing is the act of digitally signing an application by using a private key and a corresponding code-signing certificate that's trusted only in the confines of a test environment.
segment.target: Test signing is the act of digitally signing an application by using a private key and a corresponding code-signing certificate that's trusted only in the confines of a test environment.

segment.source: These are the primary ways to generate such test-signing certificates:
segment.target: These are the primary ways to generate such test-signing certificates:

segment.source: Developers can generate their own self-signed certificates.
segment.target: Developers can generate their own self-signed certificates.

segment.source: A CA can issue certificates.
segment.target: A CA can issue certificates.

segment.source: For either option, test-signing certificates must be clearly identified as appropriate only for testing.
segment.target: For either option, test-signing certificates must be clearly identified as appropriate only for testing.

segment.source: For example, the word "test" can be included in the certificate subject name, and additional legal disclaimers can be included in the certificate.
segment.target: For example, the word "test" can be included in the certificate subject name, and additional legal disclaimers can be included in the certificate.

segment.source: Production certificates that are issued by commercial CAs must be reserved for signing only public beta releases and public final releases of software and internal line-of-business software.
segment.target: Production certificates that are issued by commercial CAs must be reserved for signing only public beta releases and public final releases of software and internal line-of-business software.

segment.source: For more information, see Requirements for Device Driver Signing and Staging.
segment.target: For more information, see Requirements for Device Driver Signing and Staging.

segment.source: When you're adding test-signed driver packages to Windows, consider these points:
segment.target: When you're adding test-signed driver packages to Windows, consider these points:

segment.source: You must install the test certificates on a running operating system.
segment.target: You must install the test certificates on a running operating system.

segment.source: You can't install them offline.
segment.target: You can't install them offline.

segment.source: The certificate of the CA that issued the test certificate must be inserted in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities certificate store.
segment.target: The certificate of the CA that issued the test certificate must be inserted in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities certificate store.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If the test certificate is self-signed—for example, by using the Certificate Creation Tool (MakeCert)—the test certificate must be inserted in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities certificate store.
segment.target: If the test certificate is self-signed—for example, by using the Certificate Creation Tool (MakeCert)—the test certificate must be inserted in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities certificate store.

segment.source: The test certificate that's used to sign the driver package must be inserted in the Trusted Publishers certificate store.
segment.target: The test certificate that's used to sign the driver package must be inserted in the Trusted Publishers certificate store.

segment.source: You must add test certificates online (to a booted instance of the Windows image) before you can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) command-line tool to add test-signed drivers offline.
segment.target: You must add test certificates online (to a booted instance of the Windows image) before you can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) command-line tool to add test-signed drivers offline.

segment.source: DISM validates WHQL certifications only for boot-critical drivers.
segment.target: DISM validates WHQL certifications only for boot-critical drivers.

segment.source: But, a DISM command-line option can override this behavior.
segment.target: But, a DISM command-line option can override this behavior.

segment.source: For more information, see DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information, see DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: To install and verify test-signed drivers on 64-bit operating systems, set the Windows boot configuration to test mode by using the BCDedit tool on the destination computer.
segment.target: To install and verify test-signed drivers on 64-bit operating systems, set the Windows boot configuration to test mode by using the BCDedit tool on the destination computer.

segment.source: Test mode verifies that the driver image is signed, but certificate path validation doesn't require the issuer to be configured as a trusted root authority.
segment.target: Test mode verifies that the driver image is signed, but certificate path validation doesn't require the issuer to be configured as a trusted root authority.

segment.source: For the PnP driver installation and ranking logic to treat the driver correctly, the test certificate must be stored in the trusted certificate store of the operating system image.
segment.target: For the PnP driver installation and ranking logic to treat the driver correctly, the test certificate must be stored in the trusted certificate store of the operating system image.

segment.source: For information about test mode during development, see 64-Bit Driver Guidelines.
segment.target: For information about test mode during development, see 64-Bit Driver Guidelines.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: If an unsigned or invalid boot-critical device driver is installed on an x64-based computer, the computer will not boot.
segment.target: If an unsigned or invalid boot-critical device driver is installed on an x64-based computer, the computer will not boot.

segment.source: The unsigned or invalid boot-critical device driver will cause a Stop error.
segment.target: The unsigned or invalid boot-critical device driver will cause a Stop error.

segment.source: You should remove the driver from either the critical device database (CDDB) or its reflected location in the image.
segment.target: You should remove the driver from either the critical device database (CDDB) or its reflected location in the image.

segment.source: If you're performing an upgrade, make sure that unsigned drivers and their associated applications, services, or devices are removed or updated with a signed driver.
segment.target: If you're performing an upgrade, make sure that unsigned drivers and their associated applications, services, or devices are removed or updated with a signed driver.

segment.source: If you don't enable test mode by using BCDedit, and you have a test-signed driver installed, your computer will not boot.
segment.target: If you don't enable test mode by using BCDedit, and you have a test-signed driver installed, your computer will not boot.

segment.source: If you use DISM to remove the driver, all instances of the reflected driver package might not be removed.
segment.target: If you use DISM to remove the driver, all instances of the reflected driver package might not be removed.

segment.source: So, we recommend that you don't deploy images that have test-signed drivers installed.
segment.target: So, we recommend that you don't deploy images that have test-signed drivers installed.
